general: This law creates an organization called the "Statistics Board" to collect, analyze, and publish information about the UK's population, economy, and society. It also makes changes to the way certain government jobs are managed. The goal of the law is to improve the accuracy and usefulness of statistics so that policymakers can make better decisions.

series.short: "Establishment of the Statistics Board as a Separate Legal Entity"
series.text:
* The Statistics Board is established as a separate legal entity with its own identity and powers.
* The Board has the responsibility to exercise its functions on behalf of the Crown, meaning it acts as an agent of the government.
* The Board's property, rights, and liabilities are considered the property, rights, and liabilities of the Crown.

series.short: "UK Statistics Authority Structure and Appointments"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Statistics and Registration Service Act 2007 establishes the UK's national statistics body, the UK Statistics Authority, and outlines its structure and responsibilities.
* Simplified point 2: The Authority consists of executive and non-executive members, including the National Statistician and the Head of Assessment, who are appointed by the Minister for the Cabinet Office and the non-executive members, respectively.
* Simplified point 3: Non-executive members serve for at least one year and can be dismissed for various reasons, including absenteeism, misconduct, failure to comply with terms of appointment, or if they become unfit for office.
* Simplified point 4: Compensation may be paid to former non-executive members who cease to be members before the end of their term, subject to approval by the Minister for the Cabinet Office.
* Simplified point 5: The Authority may appoint other employees as needed, but only with the approval of the Minister for the Civil Service as to numbers and terms and conditions of employment.

series.short: Official Statistics: Definition, Production, and Publication
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines what "official statistics" mean in the context of the act. It includes statistics produced by various government departments and agencies, as well as any other statistics that may be specified by order.
* Simplified point 2: The Board must consult with these government departments and agencies before specifying any additional statistics as official.
* Simplified point 3: The Board must publish a list of official statistics at least once a year.
* Simplified point 4: The objective of the Board is to promote and safeguard the production and publication of official statistics that serve the public good, including informing the public about social and economic matters and assisting in the development and evaluation of public policy.
* Simplified point 5: To achieve this objective, the Board must promote and safeguard the quality, accessibility, and comprehensiveness of official statistics.

series.short: "Quality Control of Official Statistics in UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Office for National Statistics (ONS) must monitor and report on the quality and comprehensiveness of official statistics.
* Simplified point 2: The ONS must develop and maintain standards for official statistics and provide guidance to those responsible for producing them.
* Simplified point 3: The ONS can publish reports and findings related to official statistics, including any concerns it has about their quality or comprehensiveness.

series.short: "Designation and Production of National Statistics: Legal Framework and Responsibilities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Statistics and Registration Service Act 2007 outlines the process for designating official statistics as "National Statistics" and ensures that these statistics are produced in accordance with a code of practice.
* Simplified point 2: The code of practice includes provisions related to pre-release access to official statistics, assessments of compliance with the code, and the duties of the person producing the statistics.
* Simplified point 3: The Board is responsible for preparing and publishing a program for the assessment and re-assessment of statistics, and for consulting with various authorities before making any changes to the code of practice.
* Simplified point 4: The Board must also publish a list of statistics that are designated as National Statistics, and must maintain the existing code of practice until it is replaced by a new one.

series.short: "UK Statistics Authority's Data Collection and Publication Powers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK Statistics Authority can collect and publish data related to various topics across the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The Authority cannot release certain types of data without permission from the Scottish, Welsh, or Northern Irish governments if they relate to devolved matters.
* Simplified point 3: The Authority must maintain and publish the retail price index monthly, but cannot make changes to its calculation without consulting the Bank of England first.
* Simplified point 4: If the Bank of England believes a proposed change to the retail price index would harm investors holding index-linked bonds, the Authority cannot proceed without government approval.

series.short: "UK Statistics Authority: Empowered to Collect and Publish Vital Data"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The National Statistician and the Board have the power to collect, analyze, and publish statistics related to any topic in the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The Board can provide statistical services to anyone within or outside the UK, including providing information, conducting surveys, and collecting data.
* Simplified point 3: The Board can promote and assist statistical research by providing access to data held by them.
* Simplified point 4: The Secretary of State for the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (or other relevant authorities) can delegate certain functions related to the production of statistics to the Board.

series.short: "Transfer of Functions from Registrar General to Office for National Statistics"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The functions of the Registrar General for England and Wales related to censuses and annual abstracts of births, deaths, and marriages are transferred to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).
* Simplified point 2: The ONS will also take over the role of the Registrar General as an assessor to the Boundary Commission for England and Wales.
* Simplified point 3: This transfer is made through Schedule 1 of the Statistics and Registration Service Act 2007, which includes consequential and supplementary provisions related to the transfer of functions.

series.short: "Government Oversight and Accountability: Ensuring Efficiency and Transparency"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The board can do whatever is necessary to fulfill its objectives.
* Simplified point 2: The board needs to be efficient and not impose unnecessary burdens on others.
* Simplified point 3: If the board fails to meet its objectives or performs poorly, the minister responsible for the cabinet office can issue directives to correct the situation.
* Simplified point 4: The board must publish reports on its activities and accomplishments annually.
* Simplified point 5: These reports will be presented to various parliamentary bodies in the UK.

series.short: "National Statistical Governance Structure"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The National Statistician is responsible for ensuring the quality of official statistics and providing guidance on good practices related to official statistics.
* Simplified point 2: The National Statistician has executive functions within the Office for National Statistics, including the power to appoint and dismiss staff, and to determine the organization's policies and procedures.
* Simplified point 3: The National Statistician must establish an executive office to assist in the exercise of their functions, and can delegate any of their functions to other members of the executive office.
* Simplified point 4: The Head of Assessment is responsible for advising the Board on the exercise of its functions under sections 12(1) and 14(1), but cannot take part in any assessment or determination of the Board.
* Simplified point 5: The Board must separate the functions of assessment and determination, and must seek to ensure that employees involved in producing statistics do not advise the Board on the exercise of its functions under sections 12(1) and 14(1).

series.short: "Board's Information Sharing and Confidentiality Responsibilities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The board can use any information they obtain for any of their functions.
This means that the board can share information between different parts of their work, as long as it's related to one of their functions.
* Simplified point 2: The board must protect confidential information.
They can only share information that doesn't identify a specific person (such as statistics or general trends), and they must keep personal information private unless they have permission to share it or it's required by law.

series.short: "Data Sharing Provisions for Healthcare and Statistics"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Registrar General for England and Wales can share information related to births, deaths, marriages, and civil partnerships with the Board for the purpose of exercising the Board's functions.
* Simplified point 2: The Board can share patient registration information with the Registrar General for England and Wales for the purpose of producing population statistics.
* Simplified point 3: The Welsh Ministers can share patient registration information with the Board for the purpose of producing population statistics.
* Simplified point 4: The Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs can share information held by the Revenue and Customs with the Board for the purpose of enabling the Board to exercise one or more of its functions.

series.short: Consolidation of Statistical Agencies in the UK: Streamlining Administration through the Statistics and Registration Service Act 2007
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Statistics and Registration Service Act 2007 aims to streamline the administration of statistics and registration services in the United Kingdom by consolidating several national statistical agencies and offices into a single entity called the "Office for National Statistics" (ONS).
* Simplified point 2: The act transfers the functions, property, rights, and liabilities of the Office for National Statistics, the National Statistician, and the Registrar General for England and Wales to the new board, effectively abolishing these entities and absorbing their responsibilities into the ONS.
* Simplified point 3: The act also allows for the transfer of functions, property, rights, and liabilities from other ministers of the crown to the ONS, further consolidating the role of the ONS as the primary statistical agency in the UK.
* Simplified point 4: The ONS will provide services and facilities to the Registrar General for England and Wales, the Boundary Commission for England, and the Secretary of State or other public authorities to support the efficient carrying out of their functions related to the registration of persons in England and Wales.
* Simplified point 5: The act includes provisions for consequential amendments to other pieces of legislation, including the Local Electoral Administration and Registration Services (Scotland) Act, to ensure consistency and efficiency in the administration of statistics and registration services across the UK.

series.text:

* Simplified point 4: Relevant offices such as superintendent registrar of births, deaths, and marriages, and registrar of births and deaths are transferred to the relevant local authorities.
* Simplified point 5: Any liabilities incurred by the holders of these offices are transferred to the relevant local authorities.
* Simplified point 6: Periods of continuous employment with the relevant local authorities are recognized for pension schemes.

The Authority has executive and non-executive members, including the National Statistician and the Head of Assessment, who are appointed by the Minister for the Cabinet Office and the non-executive members, respectively. Non-executive members serve for at least one year and can be dismissed for various reasons.
